statement:
[**Theorem**]{} If $i,k$ are multi-indices in ${\mathbb{N}}^n$, and
$x=(x_1,\ldots, x_n)$, then $$\begin{aligned}
\partial^i x^k = \left\{ \begin {array}{ll} 
 \frac{k!}{(k-i)!} x^{k-i} & \mbox{if}\,\, i\le k, \\
                         0 & \mbox{otherwise}.
 \end{array} \right.\end{aligned}$$

*Proof.* The proof follows from the corresponding rule for the ordinary
derivative; if $i,k$ are in $0,1,2,\ldots$, then $$\begin{aligned}
\label{usual}
\frac{d^i}{dx^i} x^k = \left\{ \begin {array}{ll}  \frac{k!}{(k-i)!} x^{k-i} & \mbox{if}\,\, i\le k, \\
0 & \mbox{otherwise.} 
 \end{array} \right.\end{aligned}$$ Suppose $i=(i_1,\ldots, i_n)$,
$k=(k_1,\ldots, k_n)$, and $x=(x_1,\ldots, x_n)$. Then we have that
$$\begin{aligned}
\partial^i x^k &=& \frac{\partial^{|i|}}{\partial x_1^{i_1} \cdots \partial x_n^{i_n}} x_1^{k_1} \cdots x_n^{k_n} \\
 &=& \frac{\partial^{i_1}}{\partial x_1^{i_1}} x_1^{k_1} \cdot \cdots \cdot  \frac{\partial^{i_n}}{\partial x_n^{i_n}} x_n^{k_n}.\end{aligned}$$
For each $r=1,\ldots, n$, the function $x_r^{k_r}$ only depends on
$x_r$. In the above, each partial differentiation
$\partial/\partial x_r$ therefore reduces to the corresponding ordinary
differentiation $d/dx_r$. Hence, from equation \[usual\], it follows
that $\partial^i x^k$ vanishes if $i_r > k_r$ for any $r=1,\ldots, n$.
If this is not the case, i.e., if $i\le k$ as multi-indices, then for
each $r$,
$$\frac{d^{i_r}}{dx_r^{i_r}} x_r^{k_r} =  \frac{k_r!}{(k_r-i_r)!} x_r^{k_r-i_r},$$
and the theorem follows. $\Box$
